abstract.text: Update your apps to use new features, and test your apps against API changes.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The macOS 11 SDK provides support to develop apps for Macs running macOS Big Sur 11. The SDK comes bundled with Xcode 12.2, available from the Mac App Store. For information on the compatibility requirements for Xcode 12.2, see
Updating to macOS Big Sur 11.0.1 from previous versions of macOS might take significantly longer than expected. Data loss could occur if the update is interrupted. (59101197)
You might be unable to pair certain braille displays using Bluetooth. (69794099)
Workaround:
Connect these devices using USB instead.
See
and
APIs are now available for both macOS and Mac Catalyst apps. (56300909)
The default initializer on the auto-generated model interface has been deprecated in favor of
. Please use
or the newly introduced
method and handle model load errors as appropriate. (64432588)
When updating from macOS Big Sur 11 beta 2 to macOS Big Sur 11 beta 3 or later, you might be offered an unexpectedly large download rather than an incremental software update. (65753086)
Workaround:
Under the “Another update is available” text, click the “More info…” link. This reveals the incremental update where you can click the Install Now button.
You might need to adjust Energy Saver settings so your Mac doesn’t go to sleep while preparing to install macOS Big Sur 11.0.1. (63166401)

If macOS Big Sur 11.0.1 is installed into the same APFS container as previous versions of macOS Catalina 10.15, system software updates can no longer be installed on the previous versions of macOS. (64411484)
Workaround:
Update the previous version of macOS Catalina to 10.15.6 or later.

Installing a new kernel extension requires signing in as an Admin user. You must also restart your Mac to load the extension. Kernel extensions using certain deprecated KPIs won’t be loaded. For more information, see
Workaround:
During development, you can temporarily disable System Integrity Protection to allow these deprecated kernel extensions to load.

New in macOS Big Sur 11.0.1, the system ships with a built-in dynamic linker cache of all system-provided libraries. As part of this change, copies of dynamic libraries are no longer present on the filesystem. Code that attempts to check for dynamic library presence by looking for a file at a path or enumerating a directory will fail. Instead, check for library presence by attempting to
the path, which will correctly check for the library in the cache. (62986286)
Use only absolute paths with the
option of
, and don’t use a trailing
Symbols exported by both xnu and Apple kernel extensions will change. Recompile your kernel extension with each update to macOS Big Sur 11.0.1 to ensure compatibility. (64262563)
The
limit has been increased, allowing programs to receive longer argument lists. (48661669)
Darwin
now allows non-parent processes to register for
, which delivers the same values as the
family of functions in the event data. Refer to the
man page for more information. This event is subject to the following security checks:
The requesting process is allowed to send signals by sandbox restrictions.
The requesting process and the target process are running as the same user or the requesting process has root privileges. (58134463)
Kernel extensions using certain deprecated KPIs no longer load. Refer to the
. While macOS Big Sur remains in development, you can temporarily disable System Integrity Protection to allow these deprecated extensions to load. (55068348)

Key-Value Observation removal facilities now employ deterministic bookkeeping methods. Cases that would have produced hard-to-diagnose crashes, especially those where KVO signals problems accessing deallocated observer pointers or observers associated with incorrect objects, now produce an exception pinpointing which observed object needs a missed
call, and by which observers. This exception was previously thrown as ‘best effort’ when KVO could detect the problem; the new deterministic bookkeeping allows it to be thrown for all cases where
is needed.
The improved determinism also allows improved Swift API handling. Instances of
, produced by the Swift

method, take advantage of integration with this bookkeeping so they now invalidate automatically when the observed object is released,  regardless of how the object implements its KVO behavior. This applies to all usage of this API in macOS 11 Big Sur beta, including on processes built with previous versions of the SDK, and eliminates certain classes of crashes that sometimes required using the legacy API instead. (65051563)
New APIs are available for using
from Swift as part of the
framework:
A new type
can be instantiated using a subsystem and category and provides methods for logging at different levels (
The
APIs support specifying most formatting and privacy options supported by legacy
APIs.
The new APIs provide significant performance improvements over the legacy APIs.
You can now pass Swift string interpolation to the
function.
Note:
The new APIs can’t be back deployed; however, the existing
API remains available for back deployment. (22539144)
content in
might experience reduced performance. (70587571)
A
with automatic placement isn’t placed in the window toolbar. (63690384)
Select
controls, control customizations, and methods throw exceptions when used in the Mac idiom. Unsupported controls and behaviors on macOS Big Sur 11 throw exceptions as follows:
throws an exception if the button uses the macOS appearance.
and
throws an exception for any state except

is set in a non-Mac idiom view.
throws an exception when this control is added to a Mac idiom view.

throws an exception when this control is added to a Mac idiom view.

Use conditional code that respects the targeted platforms to avoid these exceptions. For example, an iOS app with an Optimized for Mac version available on macOS Big Sur 11, and an iPad idiom version available on macOS Catalina could style a
as follows:
A Mac Catalyst app targeting solely iOS and Optimized for Mac versions could conditionally compile the code as follows:
This helps ensure that your app won’t see unexpected configurations or appearances, if these behaviors change. Use caution when reading the
from a
or
to guard Mac idiom behaviors in case your app targets CarPlay or uses AirPlay to stream to another screen.
The button configuration for the
is the default button with the key equivalent of return.
The button configuration for the action with
has the key equivalent of escape.
Button configurations for actions with
will be configured with
If you apply both
and
to the same action,
takes precedence. It’s not possible to have a default button with the escape key equivalent.
The system adds an Open Recent menu automatically to applications that support opening files. The menu identifier is
has a new
property. A scene collection is a group of scenes that display together. In Catalyst, this is used to add windows to an
The default placement is
and the new scene will follow system preferences for joining collections.
Set the placement value to
to have the new scene attempt to join the collection that contains the
, or any compatible collection if
is not set.
Set the value to
to create a new collection for the scene, ignoring system preferences.
Set the value to

has a new
property that can alter the appearance of the switch in Catalyst apps running in the Mac idiom, see
for more information.
Set the
value to
to give the traditional iOS switch appearance; it will look like a native switch in Optimized Catalyst apps.
Set the

to give a traditional macOS checkbox in optimized Catalyst apps. When set to the
style, the system displays the new
property in a label within the clickable bounds of the checkbox. The
property is inert with the
style.
The
property defaults to
and renders as a sliding switch in all idioms except the Mac idiom — the only idiom where the checkbox is available.
A notable consequence of this default style of the sliding switch is that if you’re using the
style

or provide a
through other means where the intrinsic size alone was sufficient.
The default context menu presented from a
or
has missing items related to spelling and formatting.
The text you use in a
or
to look up definitions may be out of sync with the visual selection.
has a new

property that gives control over the appearance of the hairline bar in between a macOS window’s titlebar and its content. This property is especially useful when designing interfaces in the style of the new macOS Big Sur full-height sidebar.

Optimized for Mac is a new option for Catalyst apps. When optimized for Mac, Catalyst apps use Mac controls, appearances, spacing, and true font metrics, and content is no longer scaled by 77 percent. A new constant,
, has been introduced to support the new idiom. For more information on the new idiom and optimizing your Mac Catalyst app, see
, and

inlineContent.overridingTitle: Optimize the Interface of your Mac Catalyst App — WWDC20

overridingTitleInlineContent.text: Optimize the Interface of your Mac Catalyst App — WWDC20

inlineContent.text: When you deliver your iPad app on the Mac via Catalyst, your existing users on iOS no longer need to purchase your app a second time. In addition, you can manage the capabilities and App Store metadata of your app in one place.
Application preferences that include no items users can set are instead shown in the About box.
Experimental HTTP/3 support can be enabled in Safari via Experimental Features in the Developer menu, and enabled system-wide using the Terminal command
The new
struct has been renamed to
, and its
property has been renamed to
Support for 4K HDR playback of YouTube videos. (64824895)
Support for Web Extensions is now available. Existing Chrome and Firefox extensions can be converted for Safari using
and distributed through the App Store for use in Safari 14. (55707949)

Webpage Translation is now available in the U.S. and Canada. Supported languages include English, Spanish, Simplified Chinese, French, German, Russian, and Brazilian Portuguese. Safari will automatically detect if translation is available based on your Preferred Languages list. (64437861)

macOS Big Sur 11 beta improves system security by requiring an administrator password when a certificate trust settings change is made in the admin trust domain. Running as the root user alone is no longer sufficient to modify certificate trust. User trust domain settings continue to require confirmation by entering the password for the user’s account. This change may affect you if one of the following is true:
You have written scripts which call
as root.
Your process runs as root and calls the SecTrustSettingsSetTrustSettings function to trust a certificate.

Workflows that add trust settings in the admin trust domain, such as for an enterprise root certificate, may require modification if the user can’t authenticate as an administrator at the time settings are changed. (21855995)
Workaround:
Use Apple Configurator 2 to create and install a configuration profile containing your root certificate.
generic type signature has changed, adding the
generic parameter. This change doesn’t require any source changes, but it causes apps compiled using an earlier beta SDK to quit unexpectedly. (63580200)
Workaround:
Re-compile apps for macOS Big Sur 11 Beta 6 or later to resolve this issue.
A
attached to the content of a sheet will now display
and
placements below the the content of the sheet. (61180502)
A
is now automatically used when the window’s toolbar is set to Icon and Text or Text Only. (67823018)
Adding a
to a
now creates flexible spaces. (64189289)
A
now automatically creates an overflow menu item. (60104785)
Use the new
modifier to present a system interface for importing one or more files into your app, and the new
modifier to move one or more existing files to a new location. The following is an example of a simple UI for importing and moving files:
Use the new

modifier to present a system interface for exporting one or more documents from your app. In this example, an app provides a simple note-taking interface for quickly jotting down some text and then exporting it to disk:

code: // Clear the draft now that it's saved.

inlineContent.text: Use the new
modifier to present a system interface for moving one or more existing files to a new location. (66182201)
The
and
APIs have been replaced with a collection of new view modifiers.
can be converted to and from

can also now be configured with a binding to a
Introduced
as a convenient way to place multiple items in a specific location of non-customizable toolbars. (64178863)
now supports adding a secondary “current value label” that describes the current progress level of the task. Use the
to describe the overall task, and the
to provide more specific details about the progress of the task. (63580200)
and
have updated protocol requirements:
Their initializer requirement now has a single
parameter that the
and
can be read from.
Their
functions that were expected to write to an inout
parameter are now
functions that return a
instead.
The Document-based app templates in Xcode have been updated to reflect this change in API.
Source compatibility with the previous requirements will eventually be removed. (65146043)
is now redacted when the
doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/swiftui/anyview/redacted(reason:)
modifier is applied. (65047189)
is now available and allows a

to appear in-line with the rest of the content in its surrounding container. The style will adapt its appearance for different containers and platforms, such as individual menu items in a menu. (59868844)
is now available and allows a
to present its options within a menu. This style will display its options within a submenu when the
is nested within a

Using a
in a
scene will now use the correct style for macOS preference windows. The selected tab will be persisted if no selection binding is passed to the
. The window for a
scene will have an appropriate title by default. This will be either the name of the app followed by “Preferences”, or the label of the currently selected tab, if using
and
will now automatically separate their child panes’ toolbar items, aligning them with their associated split pane. (60105046)
is now supported. (63190637)
panes are now automatically resizable and no longer require an explicit frame. (63941018)
doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/swiftui/form/useractivity(_:isactive:_:)
doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/swiftui/anyview/oncontinueuseractivity(_:perform:)
are now supported. (64513929)

A new redaction reason API for applying placeholder
treatment is now available. (63288447)
You might experience kernel panics when using earlier versions of Parallels Desktop 16. (67358596)
Workaround:
Upgrade to the most-recent version of Parallels Desktop 16.
Some third-party scripts might produce unexpected results due to the change in macOS version from 10.x to 11. (62477208)
Workaround:
Set
in the calling environment, for example:

APFS-formatted backup volumes are now supported for faster, more compact, and more reliable backups. New local and network Time Machine backup destinations are formatted as APFS by default. Time Machine will continue backing up to existing HFS backup volumes. (65155545)
The
framework now requires the
entitlement. (63960391)
A new
framework provides high-level APIs to run Linux in a virtual machine. (64492914)
The function
is deprecated.
The
class is deprecated. Use
instances instead. (63690311)
doesn’t ensure uniform availability of pass library functionality between platforms and devices. (60697880)
Workaround:
Call a more specific API to check available functionality, such as

Apple Pay support is now available to Mac Catalyst apps. Two methods have been added to existing delegate protocols. No changes are required for iPad apps, but one or both of these methods must be implemented when building for Catalyst. (64187739)
The first method is an addition to the
protocol:
. This method is required for Catalyst when using
, because
, unlike
, doesn’t have knowledge of the window requesting presentation of the payment sheet. Pass back the
instance displaying the UI requesting the payment, for example,
. This method is marked as required when building for Catalyst, but is otherwise optional.
The second method depends on whether you’re using
or
. For
, use
. For
, use

This method must be implemented to request a merchant session via your server, and return it via the handler. This mirrors the security model used in WebKit, and replaces listing merchant IDs in the app’s Apple Pay entitlements. This method in turn uses the following class to send back results:
Legacy Xcode versions prior to 11.5 might unexpectedly quit when launched. (59991056)
Workaround:
Run the following command in Terminal:
then deselect Main Thread Checker in the Diagnostic tab of the Run and Test actions for each scheme in your project.
now supports the deadline
The new
and
enable direct MSR access from a guest. (50291076)

abstract.text: A Boolean value that defines whether a button’s action has a destructive effect.
Resizes the receiver’s frame so that it’s the minimum size needed to contain its cell.
A group of windows that display together as a single tabbed window.
Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether the device supports adding passes.
Returns a Boolean value that indicates whether the pass library is available.
An object that presents a sheet that prompts the user to authorize a payment request.
Methods that let you respond to user interactions with your payment authorization controller.
Requests an object that validates the identity of a merchant for a payment request.
Returns the window in which to present a payment authorization sheet.
An object that presents a sheet that prompts the user to authorize a payment request.
Requests an object that validates the identity of a merchant for a payment request.
A component that changes how RealityKit renders its entity to help with debugging.
The part of the rendering process to display as the entity’s surface texture.
A product promotion controller for customizing the order and visibility of In-App Purchases per device.
A view controller that provides a page where customers can purchase media from the App Store.
The content and behavior of the app.
A representation of a color that adapts to a given context.
A control used to select a color from the system color picker UI.
Placement for commands that manipulate the toolbar.
Command menus are stand-alone, top-level containers for controls that perform related, app-specific commands.
A container for views that you present as menu items in a context menu.
A type that you use to serialize documents to and from file.
A view that describes the current value.
A layout container that arranges its children in a horizontal line and allows the user to resize them using dividers placed between them.
A view that displays an image.
A `PickerStyle` where each option is displayed inline with other views in the current container.
A standard label for user interface items, consisting of an icon with a title.
A container that presents rows of data arranged in a single column, optionally providing the ability to select one or more members.
A control for presenting a menu of actions.
A picker style that presents the options as a menu when the user presses a button, or as a submenu when nested within a larger menu.
A view for presenting a stack of views that represents a visible path in a navigation hierarchy.
A control for selecting from a set of mutually exclusive values.
A view that shows the progress toward completion of a task.
A view that describes the current value of a progress view.
A view that describes the task represented by the progress view.
A result builder for composing a collection of scenes into a single composite scene.
A property wrapper type that reads and writes to persisted, per-scene storage.
A view that provides programmatic scrolling, by working with a proxy to scroll to known child views.
A scene that presents an interface for viewing and modifying an app’s settings.
A flexible space that expands along the major axis of its containing stack layout, or on both axes if not contained in a stack.
A view that switches between multiple child views using interactive user interface elements.
A view that displays one or more lines of read-only text.
A model that represents an item which can be placed in the toolbar or navigation bar.
A model that represents a group of `ToolbarItem`s which can be placed in the toolbar or navigation bar.
The system places the item automatically, depending on many factors including the platform, size class, or presence of other items.
The item represents a cancellation action for a modal interface.
The item represents a confirmation action for a modal interface.
The item represents a destructive action for a modal interface.
A custom parameter attribute that constructs views from closures.
Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
Apply a style that indicates the action cancels the operation and leaves things unchanged.
Apply a style that indicates the action might change or delete data.
The preferred action for the user to take from an alert.
A control that executes your custom code in response to user interactions.
Sets the image to use for the specified state.
Sets the title to use for the specified state.
A representation of the current device.
The style of interface to use on the current device.
The Open Recent menu.
A view that uses a spinning-wheel or slot-machine metaphor to show one or more sets of values.
A standard control that can initiate the refreshing of a scroll view’s contents.
An object that contains information you want the system to use when activating the session associated with a scene.
The behavior that specifies how a new scene joins a scene collection.
The scene object that requested the activation of a different scene.
A behavior that uses the system preferences for joining collections.
A behavior that creates a new collection for the new scene, ignoring system preferences.
A behavior that adds the new scene to the requesting scene’s collection and activate it, or attempts to join a compatible collection.
A behavior that adds the new scene to the requesting scene’s collection without activating it, or attempts to join a compatible collection.
An object that defines the properties associated with a hardware-based display.
A control for selecting a single value from a continuous range of values.
The color used to tint the default maximum track images.
The image representing the slider’s maximum value.
The color used to tint the default minimum track images.
The image that represents the slider’s minimum value.
Assigns a maximum track image to the specified control states.
Assigns a minimum track image to the specified control states.
Assigns a thumb image to the specified control states.
The color used to tint the default thumb images.
A control for incrementing or decrementing a value.
A control that offers a binary choice, such as on/off.
A style indicating that the switch appears as a Mac-style checkbox.
A style indicating that the switch appears as an on/off slider.
The preferred display style for the switch.
The title displayed next to a checkbox-style switch.
An object that displays an editable text area in your interface.
A scrollable, multiline text region.
An object that you use to configure the title bar of a window in a Mac app built with Mac Catalyst.
Styles that determine the type of separator displayed between the title bar and content of a window.
An interface designed for the Mac.
Attaches a gesture recognizer to the view.
Select the iPad or the Mac user interface idiom in your Mac app built with Mac Catalyst.

abstract.text: An observation that provides the points the analysis recognized.
An object that displays interactive web content, such as for an in-app browser.

A representation of a node (a file, directory, or symbolic link) in the file system.
An abstract class that declares an interface for objects that create, interpret, and validate the textual representation of values.
Removes all entries specifying an observer from the notification center's dispatch table.
Build virtualization solutions on top of a lightweight hypervisor, without third-party kernel extensions.
Starts the execution of a vCPU.
Executes a vCPU until it reaches the deadline defined in absolute time units you provide.
Enables the guest access of a managed Model-Specific Register (MSR).
Controls the guest access of a managed Model-Specific Register (MSR).
The value that indicates a vCPU deadline that never expires.
Coordinate the scheduling and synchronization of your app’s tasks, and log information to the console to diagnose issues.
An object for writing interpolated string messages to the unified logging system.
Writes a debug message to the log.
Writes information about an error to the log.
Writes a message to the log about a bug that occurs when your app executes.
The Quartz color that corresponds to the color object.
